summary_text:
-- Page 1 --
The Imperial Zenith and Collapse: The
Era of Emperor Haile Selassie I (1930-
1974)
Introduction: The Last Solomonic Emperor
The reign of Emperor Haile Selassie I, born Lij Tafari Makonnen, spanned nearly half a
century and represents the final, most consequential chapter of the Solomonic
Dynasty. He sought to transform an ancient, feudal empire into a modern, centralized state,
successfully defending its sovereignty against European aggression and establishing
Ethiopia as a key player on the world stage, particularly in the Pan-African movement.
 The Crisis of Sovereignty: The Italian Invasion
(1935-19410047_DATE__-1941)
The greatest challenge to Haile Selassie's reign was the unprovoked invasion by Fascist
Italy under Benito Mussolini in 1935. The Appeal to the League of Nations
In 1936, after the fall of his capital, Haile Selassie delivered a powerful and prophetic
address to the League of Nations in Geneva. This
achievement solidified Ethiopia's role as the diplomatic capital of Africa and was
arguably the peak of Haile Selassie's international prestige.
 The final years of Haile Selassie's reign were defined by a catastrophic confluence of
events that exposed the regime's incompetence and moral bankruptcy.
 The
Emperor's failure to transition from an absolute monarch to a constitutional ruler,
coupled with his inability to address the land question, sealed the fate of his regime
and ushered in a new, violent era of Ethiopian history.
 A History of Ethiopia. Evil Days: Thirty Years of War and Famine in Ethiopia. Transformation and Continuity in Revolutionary
Ethiopia.
summary_sentences:
-- Page 1 --
The Imperial Zenith and Collapse: The
Era of Emperor Haile Selassie I (1930-
1974)
Introduction: The Last Solomonic Emperor
The reign of Emperor Haile Selassie I, born Lij Tafari Makonnen, spanned nearly half a
century and represents the final, most consequential chapter of the Solomonic
Dynasty.

He sought to transform an ancient, feudal empire into a modern, centralized state,
successfully defending its sovereignty against European aggression and establishing
Ethiopia as a key player on the world stage, particularly in the Pan-African movement.

The Crisis of Sovereignty: The Italian Invasion
(1935-19410047_DATE__-1941)
The greatest challenge to Haile Selassie's reign was the unprovoked invasion by Fascist
Italy under Benito Mussolini in 1935.

The Appeal to the League of Nations
In 1936, after the fall of his capital, Haile Selassie delivered a powerful and prophetic
address to the League of Nations in Geneva.

This
achievement solidified Ethiopia's role as the diplomatic capital of Africa and was
arguably the peak of Haile Selassie's international prestige.

The final years of Haile Selassie's reign were defined by a catastrophic confluence of
events that exposed the regime's incompetence and moral bankruptcy.

The
Emperor's failure to transition from an absolute monarch to a constitutional ruler,
coupled with his inability to address the land question, sealed the fate of his regime
and ushered in a new, violent era of Ethiopian history.
Evil Days: Thirty Years of War and Famine in Ethiopia.

Transformation and Continuity in Revolutionary
Ethiopia.
